commit_message:
Updates cinder element

The previous cinder element was lacking a notty file and didn't
open the required ports in iptables.  This patch also allows a
developer to install the minimum required components for a
single cinder instance or (n) cinder-volume nodes.

This update results in 3 elements
cinder        : common cinder element
cinder-api    : installs the cinder api and scheduler
cinder-volume : installs the cinder volume service

Change-Id: I1ed9f67848be5716135085b6eaebc1f381ad83f9

commit_message:
Remove redundant user ownership declaration and ensure spec test coherency

swift is already set as a owner for File[] resources. This is a
simple cleanup that removes a redundant user declaration. The spec
tests did not verify that default File[] values were applied to
/var/lib/swift.

Change-Id: I608ef39ca8bbf78ca8029a65979db659184baa3f

commit_message:
Update GlusterFS driver

Since https://github.com/openstack/cinder/commit/e997f8b06ecd4ed0a13c557d621db69eb68f2f3d
got merged, glusterfs_disk_util is now removed.
This patchs aims to raise an error when using it.

Change-Id: Ic5b9b0a742482d6b7380cb59fbec6b490a206779
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>

commit_message:
L3 schedulers support

Icehouse brings new schedulers for virtual routing.
This patch aims to:
- add router_scheduler_driver flag support
- document which schedulers we could use

Change-Id: I9ed4464201e1b888ae7474221babe8e5aad38642
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/74/63974/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix package ceilometer-alarm type error on Debian

This commit:
  - Fix type error about ceilometer-alarm package name
    - See bug #1263946
  - Fix indentation on Debian params.pp

commit_message:
Support network_device_mtu of nova managed interfaces

network_device_mtu configure the MTU for nova managed network interfaces.
By default no specific network_device_mtu configuration is set. The
interface defaults will be used as they got created.

This options allows configuration of Jumbo Frame usage.

Change-Id: Ia391f3daa788c780c4492071a480052b4ef4cc37

commit_message:
Sync glossary and firstterm

Ensure that for each firstterm, we have a proper entry in the glossary:
* Use <firstterm baseform="xxx"> if the first term is spelled differently
  than the glossary entry.
* Remove some firstterm markups where no entry is in the glossary
  and adding one not useful.

Change-Id: Id7093a53f9d466db774b548749116288425af581

commit_message:
WIP: Argparse-based simple Solum CLI

* Uses argparse instead of the OpenStack Client as an option to consider
* Implements the create/delete app/assembly commands

Change-Id: I64e9606877574e6819f098874ec4542565af840b
Implements: blueprint solum-minimal-cli
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-solumclient refs/changes/65/66065/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Rackspace # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. class CommandsBase(object): """Base command parsing class""" parser = None verbose = False debug = False solum = None def __init__(self, parser): self.parser = parser self._get_global_flags() self.parser.add_argument('action', default='help', help='Action to perform on resource') action = None try: parsed, _ = parser.parse_known_args() self.verbose = parsed.verbose or False self.debug = parsed.debug or False action = parsed.action except SystemExit: # Parser has a habit of doing this when an arg is missing. pass if action in self._actions: try: self.parser.error = self.parser._error self._actions[action]() except SystemExit: print self._actions[action].__doc__ self.parser.print_help() @property def _actions(self): """Action handler""" return dict((attr, getattr(self, attr)) for attr in dir(self) if not attr.startswith('_') and callable(getattr(self, attr))) def _get_global_flags(self): """Get global flags""" self.parser.add_argument('--verbose', action='store_true', help='Show verbose output.') self.parser.add_argument('--debug', action='store_true', help='Show debug output.') def help(self): """Print this help message""" print self.__doc__ help(self._actions, 'actions') # TODO(wpm) eliminate redefinition of help def help(resources, name='resources'): """Help screen""" print("Available %s:" % name) for resource in sorted(resources): commands = resources.get(resource) docstring = "<%s %s>" % (name.capitalize(), resource) if commands.__doc__: docstring = commands.__doc__ print("\t%-20s%s" % (resource, docstring))

commit_message:
Add test fail when Keystone not available

Implemented exception handling upon Keystone client
initialization. Added method that verifies if clients
have initialized and fails if they didn`t. Added
invocation of this method to setUp classes.

Change-Id: I9437b971cc54da144f12d0368b6181d004f82604
Closes-bug: 1267946

commit_message:
correct option name in class ceph

there is not osd_default_crush_rule option in ceph.conf, the correct
name is osd_pool_default_crush_rule.

Change-Id: Ice8ec6f0bdc1e8f1c5f143134eb0fdf108ceda1f

commit_message:
Edits on section_neutron-single-flat

Update, as suggest by Matt in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/66231:
* Use lowercase database
* Use <replaceable>controller</..
* Fix another wrong usage of sql_connection

commit_message:
Tests added for check_networks "result"

Tests added to check the format of "result" field of check_networks message.
"result" field is used in UI to highlight networks parameters which have wrong values.
Some tests refactoring is made.

Change-Id: I833fa5add56b5894668edac7ea61231faae7b1fc

commit_message:
Part 1 of FloatingIP PTR record functionality

    This is part 1 - event handling in sink is Part 2 + Others.

    * Central methods update_floatingip, get_floatingip, list_floatingip
    * API according to
    * https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Designate/Blueprints/Reverse
    * Put network functionanlity into a pluggable api class (In case we want
    * more)

    blueprint floating-ip-ptrs

    Change-Id: Ic9194e5bcfc8d25126b9e84652144f58cddcccfe

Change-Id: Ib69f17ff8f2d888cf15f2cab7f46404cd201ae7e

commit_message:
Removed packages installed as dependencies by OVS plug-in agent

I removed packages installed as dependencies by the Open vSwitch
plug-in agent package on Ubuntu and Debian. For example, the
neutron-plugin-openvswitch-agent package automatically installs
the openvswitch-switch package, so the instructions shouldn't
specifically call out installing the latter.

Also, on the controller node which doesn't need to run the OVS
plug-in agent but still needs to know about the configured plug-in,
I changed the neutron-plugin-openvswitch-agent package to the
neutron-plugin-openvswitch package.

Change-Id: I13a50854149109a10155d0b6b05307a663563438
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1264184

commit_message:
Add method quote_plus in module py3kcompat.urlutils

Method quote_plus is used in some projects. We need add this method
to work with Python 3. This is an example:
https://github.com/stackforge/stackalytics/blob/master/dashboard/helpers.py#L174

Change-Id: I15ed496d947cf2b56eb6645b6b85c0745ab4f682

commit_message:
safe_log Sanitize Passwords in List of Dicts

sanitizes password fields found in lists of dicts for messages
before logging.

Change-Id: Ic3c3f7d43570fe99411a3f6bf9ef70de44104c53
Closes-Bug: #1268459
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/60/66260/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_safe_log_sanitizes_any_password_in_list_of_dicts(self): def logger_method(msg, data): self.assertEqual('<SANITIZED>', data['users'][0]['_password']) self.assertEqual('<SANITIZED>', data['users'][1]['_password']) users = [{'_host': '%', '_password': 'passw0rd', '_name': 'mydb'}, {'_host': '%', '_password': 'secret', '_name': 'newdb'}] data = {'_context_request_id': 'req-44adf4ac-12bb-44c5-be3d-da2cc73b2e05', 'users': users} rpc_common._safe_log(logger_method, 'foo', data)

subject: Removed package providing 'neutron-server' from network node
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-13 21:21:06.000000000', 'files': ['doc/install-guide/section_neutron-install.xml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/68fefd56651f2f1a5c4f49216feefa92cebeca91', 'message': "Removed package providing 'neutron-server' from network node

While fixing another bug, I noticed that the instructions for RHEL and
SUSE install a metapackage providing 'neutron-server', but do not
configure it to start on boot. In comparison, the Ubuntu instructions
install the specific package providing 'neutron-server' and
automatically configure it to start on boot.

I originally intended to patch this issue by providing instructions
for disabling 'neutron-server' in Upstart, but upon further
investigation, determined that 'neutron-server' does not need to run
on the network node, nor do any of the other packages
(neutron-l3-agent and neutron-dhcp-agent) depend on the neutron-server
package. So, this patch removes the neutron-server package from the
Ubuntu instructions and from the list of services to restart on all
distributions. I also removed the neutron-plugin-openvswitch-agent
package from the Ubuntu instructions since we shouldn't cover specific
plug-ins in this section.

Change-Id: I5c08a56b37d8aef656826fc1b644efc799aa51a7
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1265833
"}]
commit_message:
Removed package providing 'neutron-server' from network node

While fixing another bug, I noticed that the instructions for RHEL and
SUSE install a metapackage providing 'neutron-server', but do not
configure it to start on boot. In comparison, the Ubuntu instructions
install the specific package providing 'neutron-server' and
automatically configure it to start on boot.

I originally intended to patch this issue by providing instructions
for disabling 'neutron-server' in Upstart, but upon further
investigation, determined that 'neutron-server' does not need to run
on the network node, nor do any of the other packages
(neutron-l3-agent and neutron-dhcp-agent) depend on the neutron-server
package. So, this patch removes the neutron-server package from the
Ubuntu instructions and from the list of services to restart on all
distributions. I also removed the neutron-plugin-openvswitch-agent
package from the Ubuntu instructions since we shouldn't cover specific
plug-ins in this section.

Change-Id: I5c08a56b37d8aef656826fc1b644efc799aa51a7
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1265833

commit_message:
Remove unused variables

Refactor codes, remove unused variables. This patch is the first step.
F841 check in tox.ini will be enabled to make sure that there are no
userd variables in project anymore.

Change-Id: I3edd5bb5e3c203d1d3d92261ed74a201878d6f5a

commit_message:
strutils bool_from_string, allow specified default

In certain cases, we may want to return true by default, e.g see
the discussion in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/65725/, so provide
a "default" argument which can be used to override the existing default
False response.

Change-Id: I6c86b03125f263cf4843b4cf1addf9e9812f53a8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/18/66518/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def bool_from_string(subject, strict=False, default=False): `strict=False`, anything else returns the value specified by 'default'. return default
deleted_lines: def bool_from_string(subject, strict=False): `strict=False`, anything else is considered False. return False

Since the upgrade to Flask 0.10, we've not been using the correct

Closes-Bug: 1268607

commit_message:
Ensure Flask uses our JSON Encoder

Since the upgrade to Flask 0.10, we've not been using the correct
JSONEncoder. Up until today, we this was "not a problem", as
python-keystoneclient depended on simplejson, which provided the
necessary features.

python-keystoneclient 0.4.2 was released today, causing the issue
to finally surface.

Change-Id: Idc0e8f03608c80e097db2ea48b30f2bc0b8dbe5d
Closes-Bug: 1268607
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/48/66348/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update neutron options for icehouse

Also fixed up some duplicate config options due to a bug in autohelp.py.
While working through duplication options, I believe I encountered some
that weren't being output, but I'd rather spend the time fixing the tool
than manually adding those.

Change-Id: I60eb035b97d354bc57168421facafd895ace2a10

commit_message:
Add CORS mention to object storage sec of confref

CORS was a feature added in Grizzly. This simple patch adds a new
section to the config reference, detailing what it is and the single
configuration option so far.

Change-Id: Ied2d5615e7b666370bc6d0dff136d305ba8cee62
Closes-Bug: 1107326
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/91/65891/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <section xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0" xml:id="object-storage-cores"> <title>Cross-origin resource sharing</title> <para>Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is a mechanisim to allow code running in a browser (Javascript for example) make requests to a domain other then the one from where it originated. Swift supports CORS requests to containers and objects within them using metadata held on the container. </para> <para>In addition to the metadata on containers, the <literal>cors_allow_origin</literal> flag in <filename>proxy-server.conf</filename> may be used to set a list of hosts that are included with any CORS request by default.</para> </section>

commit_message:
Add a fake ZooKeeper driver

This patch add a new driver which mimic a Kazoo client
without the need to use a real zookeeper server.

The dependency Zake (written by Joshua Harlow:harlowja@gmail.com)
has been added which provides the Kazoo API.

Change-Id: I53ca9ac972d6e2dca2f9e04b6187ee0545813e74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/85/63385/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fake_zookeeper = tooz.drivers.fake_zookeeper:FakeZooKeeperDriver

commit_message:
Add new modprobe-blacklist element.

This element can be used to provide a custom list
of modules via DIB_MODPROBE_BLACKLIST which
will be disabled via modprobe.d/blacklist.conf.

I'm using this to disable network adapters on the
Red Hat TripleO rack where the devices can't be
explicitly disabled via the BIOS.

Change-Id: I8a0a8ee05fa62628434d7f6422577dbf5cdd7a2e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/25/66425/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -ex MODULES_LIST=${DIB_MODPROBE_BLACKLIST:?"Please set DIB_MODPROBE_BLACKLIST."} for mod_name in $MODULES_LIST; do echo "blacklist $mod_name" >> /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf done

subject: Add package support to source-repositories
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-09 19:08:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/d7b0a259403ddc5bbfb23f5565cbc23828cad3fd', 'message': 'Add package support to origin-repositories

Adds a new "package" type to origin-repositories. When the package type
is specified in an origin-repository-* file the package name and type
"package" need to be specified like so:

nova package

The existing map-packages mechanism can be used to map the specified
package name to the actual distribution package names.  The
pre-configured package repositories on the image will be used to install
the packages during the install.d phase of the image build.

If the repo type is package, an environment.d hook script is updated
with an environment variable which is sourced by dib-run-parts. This is
so that other hooks, particularly in install.d, will know what repo type
was used and can make the correct decision about doing a source install
or not.

Change-Id: Ief4e524664cd32d2087aeb3b1766f05e017de91e
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-01-09 21:46:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/6ab0dfa53e7563d40e99572194485e9622e8234e', 'message': 'Add package support to origin-repositories

Adds a new "package" type to origin-repositories. When the package type
is specified in an origin-repository-* file the package name and type
"package" need to be specified like so:

nova package

The existing map-packages mechanism can be used to map the specified
package name to the actual distribution package names.  The
pre-configured package repositories on the image will be used to install
the packages during the install.d phase of the image build.

If the repo type is package, an environment.d hook script is updated
with an environment variable which is sourced by dib-run-parts. This is
so that other hooks, particularly in install.d, will know what repo type
was used and can make the correct decision about doing a source install
or not.

Change-Id: Ief4e524664cd32d2087aeb3b1766f05e017de91e

commit_message:
Add package support to source-repositories

Adds a new "package" type to source-repositories. When the package type
is specified in an origin-repository-* file the package name and type
"package" need to be specified like so:

nova package

The existing map-packages mechanism can be used to map the specified
package name to the actual distribution package names.  The
pre-configured package repositories on the image will be used to install
the packages during the install.d phase of the image build.

If the repo type is package, an environment.d hook script is updated
with an environment variable which is sourced by dib-run-parts. This is
so that other hooks, particularly in install.d, will know what repo type
was used and can make the correct decision about doing a source install
or not.

Change-Id: Ief4e524664cd32d2087aeb3b1766f05e017de91e

commit_message:
Use dynamic catalog for keystone on SUSE

Keystone uses dynamic catalog by default, which supports management
commands. Meanwhile, current static catalog default_catalog.templates
is lack of ceilometer endpoints.

This patch simply removes the catalog configure step to use default
setting.

Change-Id: Ie852c0dc4dc03b7120116dd25b10ee58a5d91e3e
Closes-Bug: #1267322
(cherry picked from commit b3ae3222b34f7282f875658387228de650f81d77)

commit_message:
Allow passing extra args to JobExecutionsManager.create()

Java job types require additional parameters beyond cluster_id and
configs.  Add an optional dictionary and an update call to allow
for additional key/value settings.

Closes-Bug: #1268695

Change-Id: I995e648a939063170d1a2ac7040493351fb67f74

commit_message:
Retry link check up to 10 times.

Updates the dhcp-all-interfaces element so that the link
check tries up to 10 times.

On some of my machines 3 times (seconds) doesn't appear to
be quite long enough...

Change-Id: Ibf7015162fc890d4de8a417b868b0301146944c0

deleted_lines: TRIES=3

commit_message:
Removing the config-applier element

This is pretty much a duplicate of t-i-e/elements/os-apply-config, isn't used
in tripleo and the upstart script is out of date. We don't need to carry this.

Change-Id: I2b23d5930afae42cff28e2d5ce3d6c84224afa4a

commit_message:
Install os-refresh-config from release into a venv

We had been installing this from a git repository into the global site-packages.
Which is inconsistent with how we install os-apply-config.

Change-Id: I1a2167d3e71cc97bd387191b44eb4d59b62ce00c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/52/66352/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Install os-collect-config from release into a venv

We had been installing this from a git repository into the global site-packages.
Which is inconsistent with how we install os-apply-config.

Change-Id: I262f1159ca58d6e225567d718460f78474f2db48

commit_message:
Add a wait condition to undercloud stack

Using of Heat wait conditions allows us to reliably reason when a
stack creation is complete (as the completion handle is triggered
when os-refresh-config completes).

Change-Id: I89725143532177a0b4aea23c1c31bc7737da0896

commit_message:
Fix devstack engine test coverage

One test per method with proper mocking. Add tests localrc generation

Change-Id: Id48e00f03909594b07c9763aa1aa01769bb0366d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/12/64012/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.engine = devstack.DevstackEngine(self.deployment) self.deployment = SAMPLE_CONFIG.copy() self.deployment['config'] = {'name': 42} self.assertEqual(self.engine.localrc['ADMIN_PASSWORD'], 'secret') def test_prepare_server(self): server = mock.Mock() self.engine.prepare_server(server) filename = server.ssh.execute_script.mock_calls[0][1][0] self.assertTrue(filename.endswith('rally/deploy/engines/' 'devstack/install.sh')) @mock.patch('rally.deploy.engines.devstack.open', create=True) @mock.patch('rally.serverprovider.provider.Server') def test_deploy(self, m_server, m_open): s2 = mock.Mock() from_credentials = mock.Mock(return_value=s2) m_server.from_credentials = from_credentials server = mock.Mock() server.get_credentials.return_value = {} self.engine.configure_devstack = mock.Mock() self.engine.start_devstack = mock.Mock() self.engine._vm_provider = mock.Mock() self.engine._vm_provider.create_servers.return_value = [server] with mock.patch.object(self.engine, 'prepare_server') as ps: self.engine.deploy() ps.assert_called_once_with(server) self.assertEqual([mock.call.from_credentials({'user': 'rally'})], m_server.mock_calls) self.engine.configure_devstack.assert_called_once_with(s2) self.engine.start_devstack.assert_called_once_with(s2) @mock.patch('rally.deploy.engines.devstack.os') @mock.patch('rally.deploy.engines.devstack.tempfile') @mock.patch('rally.deploy.engines.devstack.open', create=True) def test_configure_devstack(self, m_open, m_tmpf, m_os): m_tmpf.mkstemp.return_value = (42, 'tmpnam') fake_file = mock.Mock() m_open.return_value = fake_file server = mock.Mock() self.engine.localrc = {'k1': 'v1', 'k2': 'v2'} self.engine.configure_devstack(server) calls = [ mock.call.ssh.execute('git', 'clone', DEVSTACK_REPO), mock.call.ssh.upload('tmpnam', '~/devstack/localrc'), ] self.assertEqual(calls, server.mock_calls) fake_file.asser_has_calls([ mock.call.write('k1=v1\n'), mock.call.write('k2=v2\n'), ]) os_calls = [ mock.call.close(42), mock.call.unlink('tmpnam'), ] self.assertEqual(os_calls, m_os.mock_calls) def test_start_devstack(self): server = mock.Mock() self.assertTrue(self.engine.start_devstack(server)) server.ssh.execute.assert_called_once_with('~/devstack/stack.sh')
deleted_lines: import os self.de = devstack.DevstackEngine(self.deployment) self.deployment['config']['name'] = 42 self.assertEqual(self.de.localrc['ADMIN_PASSWORD'], 'secret') def test_deploy(self): with mock.patch('rally.sshutils.SSH') as ssh: self.de.deploy() config_tmp_filename = ssh.mock_calls[4][1][0] call = mock.call install_script = 'rally/deploy/engines/devstack/install.sh' expected = [ call('example.com', 'root', 22, None), call().execute_script(os.path.abspath(install_script)), call('example.com', 'rally', 22, None), call().execute('git', 'clone', DEVSTACK_REPO), call().upload(config_tmp_filename, '~/devstack/localrc'), call().execute('~/devstack/stack.sh')] self.assertEqual(expected, ssh.mock_calls)

commit_message:
Setup for openstack-doc-tools

Add files to allow us gating via:
tox -e checkbuild
tox -e checkniceness
etc

Add .gitignore to ignore files used by gating.

Add initial README file to document this

Change-Id: I821e1848bb364f7514c54e87f5d29d4254b9e025
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/database-api refs/changes/34/66434/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [tox] minversion = 1.6 envlist = checkniceness,checksyntax,checkdeletions,checkbuild skipsdist = True [testenv] setenv = VIRTUAL_ENV={envdir} LANG=en_US.UTF-8 LANGUAGE=en_US:en LC_ALL=C deps = -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt [testenv:venv] commands = {posargs} [testenv:checkniceness] commands = openstack-doc-test --api-site --check-niceness {posargs} [testenv:checksyntax] commands = openstack-doc-test --api-site --check-syntax {posargs} [testenv:checkdeletions] commands = openstack-doc-test --api-site --check-deletions {posargs} [testenv:checkbuild] commands = openstack-doc-test --api-site --check-build {posargs}

commit_message:
Add check_and_fence method and tests for nailgun agent:NodeAgent

To run unit tests use:
rspec ./bin/agent_spec.rb --color --format documentation

Make sure you have:
ruby 1.9.3p429 / 1.8.7p371
rspec 2.14.7
---------------------
httpclient (2.3.4.1)
json (1.8.1)
logger (1.2.8)
ohai (6.20.0)
rethtool (0.0.3)

Implements: blueprint fencing-in-nailgun-agent

Change-Id: Ic7d9d38a65514a89aa1581109757fb1ed8a6702c
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bogdando@mail.ru>
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/25/64425/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'test/unit' require 'mocha/setup' require 'rubygems' # stub the root rights for agent script under test Process.stubs(:euid).returns(0) # use load for agent script w/o '.rb' extension load './bin/agent' # fixtures $xml_all_ok = <<END <xpath-query> <nvpair id="status-node-7.test.domain.local-root_free" name="root_free" value="5"/> <nvpair id="status-node-8.test.domain.local-root_free" name="root_free" value="5"/> <nvpair id="status-node-9.test.domain.local-root_free" name="root_free" value="5"/> </xpath-query> END $xml_need_fence1 = <<END <xpath-query> <nvpair id="status-node-7.test.domain.local-root_free" name="root_free" value="5"/> <nvpair id="status-node-8.test.domain.local-root_free" name="root_free" value="5"/> <nvpair id="status-node-9.test.domain.local-root_free" name="root_free" value="0"/> </xpath-query> END $xml_need_fence2 = <<END <xpath-query> <nvpair id="status-node-7.test.domain.local-root_free" name="root_free" value="0"/> <nvpair id="status-node-8.test.domain.local-root_free" name="root_free" value="5"/> <nvpair id="status-node-9.test.domain.local-root_free" name="root_free" value="0"/> </xpath-query> END $fl = StringIO.new("target") describe NodeAgent do before :each do logger = Logger.new(STDOUT) logger.level = Logger::DEBUG url = 'http://127.0.0.1:8000/api' @agent = NodeAgent.new(logger, url) @agent.stubs(:random).returns(0) File.stub(:exist?).with("/etc/nailgun_systemtype").and_return(true) File.stub(:open).with("/etc/nailgun_systemtype", "r").and_return($fl) end describe "#new" do it "takes logger and url parameters and returns a nailgun agent instance" do @agent.should be_an_instance_of NodeAgent end end # Fence daemon tests describe "#check_and_fence" do before :each do @agent.stubs(:is_corosync_up).returns(true) @agent.stubs(:get_system_type).returns("target") end it "Check N/A: should return 1, if system type file is missing" do File.stub(:exist?).with("/etc/nailgun_systemtype").and_return(false) @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(1) end it "Check N/A: should return 1, if fence action is not applicable because of wrong system type" do @agent.stubs(:get_system_type).returns("bootstrap") @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(1) end it "Check N/A: should return 1, if corosync is not ready" do @agent.stub(:is_corosync_up).and_return(false) @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(1) end it "Check N/A: should return 1, if none of free space monitoring ocf resources ready" do @agent.stubs(:get_free_root_space_from_CIB).returns(nil) @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(1) end it "Check PASSED: should return 0, if nodes in the cluster don't need fencing by root free space criteria" do @agent.stubs(:get_free_root_space_from_CIB).returns(REXML::Document.new($xml_all_ok).root.elements['/xpath-query']) @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(0) end it "Check FAILED: if one node must be fenced and is online, should issue fence command to corosync and return 2" do @agent.stubs(:get_free_root_space_from_CIB).returns(REXML::Document.new($xml_need_fence1).root.elements['/xpath-query']) expected_node = "node-9.test.domain.local" expected_nodes = [ expected_node ] @agent.stub(:exec).with( "/usr/sbin/cibadmin --query --xpath \"//node_state[@uname='#{expected_node}']\" | grep -q 'crmd=\"online\"'" ).and_return(0) @agent.stub(:exec).with( "/usr/sbin/crm --force node fence #{expected_node}" ).and_return(0) @agent.should_receive(:is_offline).with(expected_node).exactly(1).times.and_return(false) @agent.should_receive(:fence_nodes).with(expected_nodes).exactly(1).times.and_return(2) @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(2) end it "Check FAILED: if some nodes must be fenced and are online, should issue fence commands to corosync and return 2" do @agent.stubs(:get_free_root_space_from_CIB).returns(REXML::Document.new($xml_need_fence2).root.elements['/xpath-query']) expected_node1 = "node-7.test.domain.local" expected_node2 = "node-9.test.domain.local" expected_nodes = [ expected_node1, expected_node2 ] expected_nodes.each do |node| @agent.stub(:exec).with( "/usr/sbin/cibadmin --query --xpath \"//node_state[@uname='#{node}']\" | grep -q 'crmd=\"online\"'" ).and_return(0) @agent.stub(:exec).with( "/usr/sbin/crm --force node fence #{node}" ).and_return(0) @agent.should_receive(:is_offline).with(node).exactly(1).times.and_return(false) end @agent.should_receive(:fence_nodes).with(expected_nodes).exactly(1).times.and_return(2) @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(2) end it "Check FAILED: should return 3, if some nodes are online and has been ordered to fence, but some of crm commands were not issued for some reasons" do @agent.stubs(:get_free_root_space_from_CIB).returns(REXML::Document.new($xml_need_fence2).root.elements['/xpath-query']) expected_node1 = "node-7.test.domain.local" expected_node2 = "node-9.test.domain.local" expected_nodes = [ expected_node1, expected_node2 ] expected_nodes.each do |node| @agent.stub(:exec).with( "/usr/sbin/cibadmin --query --xpath \"//node_state[@uname='#{node}']\" | grep -q 'crmd=\"online\"'" ).and_return(0) @agent.should_receive(:is_offline).with(node).exactly(1).times.and_return(false) end @agent.stub(:exec).with( "/usr/sbin/crm --force node fence #{expected_node1}" ).and_return(0) @agent.stub(:exec).with( "/usr/sbin/crm --force node fence #{expected_node2}" ).and_return(6) @agent.should_receive(:fence_nodes).with(expected_nodes).exactly(1).times.and_return(3) @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(3) end it "Check consider PASSED behavior: should exclude itself from the fencing and return 0" do @agent.stubs(:get_free_root_space_from_CIB).returns(REXML::Document.new($xml_need_fence1).root.elements['/xpath-query']) @agent.stubs(:is_offline).returns(false) @agent.stubs(:_system_info).returns({ :fqdn => 'node-9.test.domain.local' }) @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(0) end it "Check consider PASSED behavior: should exclude offline nodes from the fencing and return 0" do @agent.stubs(:get_free_root_space_from_CIB).returns(REXML::Document.new($xml_need_fence1).root.elements['/xpath-query']) @agent.stubs(:is_offline).returns(true) @agent.check_and_fence.should eq(0) end end end

commit_message:
Prevent caller from specifying id during PciDevice.create()

The patch is to remove id when it was set before creating a PCI device
in objects.

Related to blueprint icehouse-objects.

Change-Id: Idd6d40e88f7251307504c945453281656eebb073

commit_message:
Validate further XML files

Do simple XML validation of .xsd, .xsl, .xjb files - just for well-formed XML,
no schema validation yet.

Fix a bug introduced with version 0.2 that we did not use a schema
for .wadl files. Testing this, there were too many errors with the RelaxNG
validation, so use XMLSchema as recommend by David Cramer.

Added XMLSchema files for local parsing.

Change-Id: I589f00a2e3dc46b6b3ba5e965fa9d4eba6d1a295
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/44/66044/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: WADL_XSD = "http://docs.rackspace.com/rackbook/wadl.xsd" # NOTE(jaegerandi): We could use the RelaxNG instead # like follows but this gives quite some errors at the # moment, so only validate using the XMLSchema #url = WADL_RNG #relaxng_doc = etree.parse(url, base_url=BASE_RNG) #return etree.RelaxNG(relaxng_doc) url = WADL_XSD schema = etree.parse(url) return etree.XMLSchema(schema)def is_xml_like(filename): """Returns true if file is in some XML format we handle return (filename.endswith(('.xml', '.xsd', '.xsl', '.wadl', '.xjb')) and not filename.endswith('pom.xml')) print("Checking syntax and niceness of XML files...") elif check_syntax: print("Checking syntax of XML files...") elif check_niceness: print("Checking niceness of XML files...") validate_schema = True if is_api_site: # Files ending with ".xml" in subdirectories of # wadls and samples files are not docbook files. if (f.endswith('.xml') and ("wadls" in f or "samples" in f)): validate_schema = False # Right now we can only validate docbook .xml # and .wadl files with a schema elif not f.endswith(('.wadl', '.xml')): validate_schema = False print("Check failed, validated %d XML files with %d failures.\n" print("Check passed, validated %d XML files.\n" % no_validated) modified_files = filter(is_xml_like, modified_files) if (is_xml_like(f) and f not in exceptions):
deleted_lines: url = WADL_RNG relaxng_doc = etree.parse(url, base_url=BASE_RNG) return etree.RelaxNG(relaxng_doc)def is_xml_wadl(filename): """Returns true if file ends a valid .xml or .wadl file. return (filename.endswith(('.xml', '.wadl')) and not filename.endswith('/pom.xml')) print("Checking syntax and niceness of xml and wadl files...") elif check_syntax: print("Checking syntax of xml and wadl files...") elif check_niceness: print("Checking niceness of xml and wadl files...") # Files ending with ".xml" in subdirectories of # wadls and samples files are not docbook files. # We cannot validate with a schema for these if (is_api_site and ("wadls" in f or "samples" in f)): validate_schema = False else: validate_schema = True print("Check failed, validated %d xml/wadl files with %d failures.\n" print("Check passed, validated %d xml/wadl files.\n" % no_validated) modified_files = filter(is_xml_wadl, modified_files) if (f.endswith(('.xml', '.wadl')) and f != 'pom.xml' and f not in exceptions):

commit_message:
Only add ceilometer user to nova group if using compute agent

When using ceilometer outside of the compute context (ex: with the
swift middleware), puppet-ceilometer attempts to add the user to
the nova group which does not (and probably should not) exist on
the swift nodes.

Change-Id: I6cc68152325a967c024ce611f92a90ce0afba8cc

commit_message:
Update Obj-auditor to support multiple storage policies

objects will be stored in directories like 'objects', 'objects-1',
'objects-2'..., so simply update obj-auditor to audit these data
also.

bp: ec-auditor

Change-Id: Idf1b24a78eb1c34d5fca3a79d8e914bc23ebff0a

commit_message:
Add marconi client

Add and initialize marconi client in engine.clients, so it can
be used in later patches.

Marconi bp,
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/marconi/+spec/heat-template

Implements: blueprint mqaas-marconi-resource

Change-Id: I1f25145386428a6d127e41f1fff839d6d88a512d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/35/61035/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def marconi(self): return self.stack.clients.marconi()

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-08 08:10:21.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/identity/controllers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/ebe0ec90662e2345c3aae54cc571c4122efccaf2', 'message': 'Allow user creating with fields have ":" or "-"

If we define custom fields which ":" or "-", when creating user,keystone
will convert ":" and "-" to "_". It should not be so.

Change-Id: If0467421d5b18a9cdc2c88fecfb1befd23307e5f
Closes-bug: #1241218
'}]
commit_message:
Allow user creating with fields have ":" or "-"

If we define custom fields which ":" or "-", when creating user,keystone
will convert ":" and "-" to "_". It should not be so.

Change-Id: If0467421d5b18a9cdc2c88fecfb1befd23307e5f
Closes-bug: #1241218
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/29/65429/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ref = self._assign_unique_id(user)
deleted_lines: user = self._normalize_dict(user) ref = self._assign_unique_id(self._normalize_dict(user))

subject: Add API schema for v3 admin_actions API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-03 01:54:45.000000000', 'files': ['nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/v3/admin_actions_schema.py', 'nova/api/validation/validators.py', 'nova/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/admin_actions.py', 'nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/test_admin_actions.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/de1e393b928cc9007442d169f61b58ac69089782', 'message': 'Add API schema for v3 admin_actions API

By defining the API schema, it is possible to separate the validation
code from the API method. The API method can be more simple.
In addition, a response of API validation error can be consistency for
whole of Nova APIs.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-validation-fw

Change-Id: Id58e0bd2e07c634e1649a41b8333e3657d7e08cf
'}]
commit_message:
Add API schema for v3 admin_actions API

By defining the API schema, it is possible to separate the validation
code from the API method. The API method can be more simple.
In addition, a response of API validation error can be consistency for
whole of Nova APIs.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-validation-fw

Change-Id: Id58e0bd2e07c634e1649a41b8333e3657d7e08cf

subject: Fix flavor extra_spec usages
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-14 04:46:24.000000000', 'files': ['doc/common/section_cli_nova_customize_flavors.xml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/ee3139ef4f9cba1e2d13b3531a49a0dd1129191a', 'message': 'Fix flavor extra_spec usages

"nova-manage" command is deprecated and "nova flavor-key" can set
flavor extra_spec instead. This patch changes the usage to show
"nova flavor-key".
In addition, "nova flavor-set" command does not exist.
This patch fixes it with "nova flavor-key" command.

Change-Id: If41899cf0af463ccc2db5127d53398f73e3a26a7
'}]
commit_message:
Fix flavor extra_spec usages

"nova-manage" command is deprecated and "nova flavor-key" can set
flavor extra_spec instead. This patch changes the usage to show
"nova flavor-key".
In addition, "nova flavor-set" command does not exist.
This patch fixes it with "nova flavor-key" command.

Change-Id: If41899cf0af463ccc2db5127d53398f73e3a26a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/96/66496/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: with the nova tool. For example, to configure the I/O <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova flavor-key m1.small set quota:read_bytes_sec=10240000</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova flavor-key m1.small set quota:write_bytes_sec=10240000</userinput></screen> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova flavor-key m1.medium set disk_write_bytes_sec=10485760</userinput></screen> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova flavor-key m1.small set quota:inbound_average=10240</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova flavor-key m1.small set quota:outbound_average=10240</userinput></screen>
deleted_lines: with the nova-manage tool. For example, to configure the I/O <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova-manage flavor set_key --name m1.small --key quota:read_bytes_sec --value 10240000</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova-manage flavor set_key --name m1.small --key quota:write_bytes_sec --value 10240000</userinput></screen> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova flavor-set m1.medium set disk_write_bytes_sec=10485760</userinput></screen> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova-manage flavor set_key --name m1.small --key quota:inbound_average --value 10240</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>nova-manage flavor set_key --name m1.small --key quota:outbound_average --value 10240</userinput></screen>

Mention kvm-ok for checking hw virt

Mention kvm-ok for checking hardware virtualization support in
devtest_setup.

commit_message:
Update ceilometer.conf.sample

Recent version of python-keystoneclient introduces new option,
include_service_catalog, so update ceilometer.conf.sample file.

Change-Id: I6af92166a2058ed541e79bf057b550ba1137c032
Closes-bug: 1268796
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/81/66481/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Use the new xml namespace in v3 API

This patch uses the new xml namespace XMLNS_V3 in V3 API.

commit_message:
Simple Certificate Extension

Implement the Simple Certificate Extension for retrieving the signing
certificates from a server.

This extension brings in a simple Pecan extension router that allows new
extensions to be developed with Pecan/wSME. The extension and the router
are grouped because the extension is about the simplest test of the
router as possible.

Change-Id: I7811480f2e83f10ee26e1d9fe60fb52834d07d19
Closes-Bug: #1259011
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/10/62810/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo.config import cfg import pecan from pecan import rest from keystone.common import wsgi CONF = cfg.CONF class Certificates(rest.RestController): @pecan.expose(content_type='application/x-pem-file') def get_all(self): with open(CONF.signing.certfile, 'r') as cert_file: data = cert_file.read() pecan.response.status_code = 200 return data class RootController(object): certificates = Certificates() @pecan.expose(content_type='application/x-pem-file') def ca(self): with open(CONF.signing.ca_certs, 'r') as ca_file: data = ca_file.read() pecan.response.status_code = 200 return data class SimpleCertExtension(wsgi.PecanExtensionRouter): controllers = {'/OS-SIMPLE-CERT/{path_info:.*}': RootController()}

commit_message:
Resource api lack of first&last sample timestamps

The first & last sample timestamps for any meter
associated with a resource are calculated when
we retrieve the Resource models from the storage
driver,but mismatch between the Resource model and
the Resource representation returned by the API.

Change-Id: I5a36558e85d8799bab6deb38a1774e8d790157a5
Closes-Bug: #1262335

deleted_lines: timestamp = datetime.datetime "UTC date and time of the last update to any meter for the resource" timestamp=datetime.datetime.utcnow(),

commit_message:
Add domain boundaries to user/group/project lists

With respect to the domain concept, the access of a user should be
contained inside the scoped project or domain. This is a preliminary
support of domain in the three listing features.

Implements: blueprint Domain-Level Trusts
Change-Id: Ifa14c7a22a79d911fcc783eae35696e959e54413
Signed-off-by: Bo Tang <btang@cs.utsa.edu>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/02/63602/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (botang)sync project domain id in token with context domain_id # this makes sure that context has 'domain_id' in 'query_string' # so that only projects in the domain will be returned try: token_ref = self.token_api.get_token(context['token_id']) except exception.TokenNotFound: LOG.warning(_('Invalid token in _get_domain_id_for_request')) raise exception.Unauthorized() if 'domain_id' not in context['query_string']: context['query_string']['domain_id'] = \ token_ref['token_data']['token']['project']['domain']['id'] # (botang)sync project domain id in token with context domain_id # this makes sure that context has 'domain_id' in 'query_string' # so that only users in the domain will be returned try: token_ref = self.token_api.get_token(context['token_id']) except exception.TokenNotFound: LOG.warning(_('Invalid token in _get_domain_id_for_request')) raise exception.Unauthorized() if 'domain_id' not in context['query_string']: context['query_string']['domain_id'] = \ token_ref['token_data']['token']['project']['domain']['id'] # (botang)sync project domain id in token with context domain_id # this makes sure that context has 'domain_id' in 'query_string' # so that only groups in the domain will be returned try: token_ref = self.token_api.get_token(context['token_id']) except exception.TokenNotFound: LOG.warning(_('Invalid token in _get_domain_id_for_request')) raise exception.Unauthorized() if 'domain_id' not in context['query_string']: context['query_string']['domain_id'] = \ token_ref['token_data']['token']['project']['domain']['id']

commit_message:
Fixed a problem in iSCSI multipath

Multipathing during copy image to volume and copy volume to image
operations doesn't work properly if there are different targets
associated with different portals for a mulitpath device.

Change-Id: I21ac6715b470b148340cc231b994ffd0fbe7c9bd
Closes-Bug: #1266048
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/58/64958/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fixed a problem in iSCSI multipath

Multipathing for attach volume and detach volume operations
doesn't work properly if there are different targets
associated with different portals for a mulitpath device.

Change-Id: Ie53e7b228c672fa1a911c1437c1e35016f4d7226
Closes-Bug: #1266051

commit_message:
OpenStack theme for sphinx docs

Use the OpenStack theme for Sphinx documentation.

This theme is the same one used by python-keystoneclient.

Change-Id: I2f2d1b762618e44c63d55822dad3030eb6e332e5

commit_message:
REST API for software config/deployment

This REST API creates two new base paths to manage config and deployment
entities:
* /{tenant_id}/software_configs
* /{tenant_id}/software_deployments

This is a POC change which currently lacks tests.

partial blueprint: hot-software-config-rest
Change-Id: I72259a454713ed1bfe423ba10e35a6f1e6a0dbee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/78/58878/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from webob import exc from heat.api.openstack.v1 import util from heat.common import wsgi from heat.rpc import client as rpc_client class SoftwareConfigController(object): """ WSGI controller for Software config in Heat v1 API Implements the API actions """ def __init__(self, options): self.options = options self.engine = rpc_client.EngineClient() def default(self, req, **args): raise exc.HTTPNotFound() @util.tenant_local def index(self): """ List software configs. """ return {'software_configs': []} @util.tenant_local def show(self, req, config_id): """ Gets detailed information for a software config """ sc = self.engine.show_software_config( req.context, config_id) return {'software_config': sc} @util.tenant_local def create(self, req, body): """ Create a new software config """ create_data = { 'name': body.get('name'), 'config': body.get('config'), 'inputs': body.get('inputs'), 'outputs': body.get('outputs'), } sc = self.engine.create_software_config( req.context, **create_data) return {'software_config': sc} @util.tenant_local def delete(self, req, config_id): """ Delete an existing software config """ res = self.engine.delete_software_config(req.context, config_id) if res is not None: raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(res['Error']) raise exc.HTTPNoContent() def create_resource(options): """ Software configs resource factory method. """ # TODO(zaneb) handle XML based on Content-type/Accepts deserializer = wsgi.JSONRequestDeserializer() serializer = wsgi.JSONResponseSerializer() return wsgi.Resource( SoftwareConfigController(options), deserializer, serializer)

commit_message:
check hypervisor's trust level instead compute for TrustedFilter

The TrustedFilter uses host_state.host as the name that will be checked
against the remote attestation service.

This works for the KVM case because the compute node and the hypervisor
are the same; however we must be checking host_state.nodename which is
the hostname for the hypervisor which will be registered with the
attestation server.

Change-Id: I6065b9400dd329d37a1ff90179423f259d53713c
Closes-bug: #1223452

deleted_lines: service = compute['service'] if not service: LOG.warn(_("No service for compute ID %s") % compute['id']) continue host = service['host'] host = host_state.host

commit_message:
Added profiler notification plugin

This plugin collects profiler messages into ceilometer.
Currently it listens on 2 exchanges: nova + separate rally exchange.
Later all messages should only be sent to rally exchange.

Implements blueprint profiler-rpc-collector

Change-Id: Iac7c68066164dfd010e1485515f0d813a77c959e

commit_message:
Proposition to find the original binding in the ML2 context

The original binding is usefull to have the original segment
informations during the delete_port_postcommit
This is an alternative to
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/61583/

Change-Id: I68b08fd97368bb8644bdc8f6b8efed465538ebc0

commit_message:
WIP: Shell based on python-openstack client.

1. This adds python-openstack client as dependency.
2. This copies and modifies shell.py and clientmanager.py.

TODO:

The client should be modified to accept token so that token can be passed to the
client as it is done in other clients. Now in shell.py we are relying to token
from auth plugin set on http client.

Change-Id: Ib191a17b0da80049be93cd2da7d24412da8fcb3c

commit_message:
Make assertQueryStringIs usage simpler

As requested in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/65728/, this "fixes"
assertQueryStringIs so it takes a query string, rather than a dict
of lists, which is a less convenient format in many tests.

Change-Id: Ib4c49ba71f7e12bb5bcb4dfde77974f3418c7854

commit_message:
Verify token binding in auth_token middleware

The server side has had token bind checking implemented for a while. Now
that it is possible to generate bound tokens auth_token middleware
should be capable of verifying them.

Change-Id: I4f9c5855ab3102333b0738864c506e2501bf9c7e

added_lines: ' defined) this string is used for key derivation.'), cfg.StrOpt('enforce_token_bind', default='permissive', help='Used to control the use and type of token binding. Can' ' be set to: disabled to not check token binding. permissive' ' (default) to validate binding information if the bind type' ' is of a form known to the server and ignore it if not.' ' strict, like permissive but if the bind type is unknown the' ' token will be rejected. required, any form of token binding' ' is needed to be allowed. Or the name of a binding method that' ' must be present in tokens.') token_info = self._validate_user_token(user_token, env) def _validate_user_token(self, user_token, env, retry=True): self._confirm_token_bind(data, env) def _confirm_token_bind(self, data, env): bind_mode = self._conf_get('enforce_token_bind') if bind_mode == 'disabled': return if not data: raise InvalidUserToken('Token authorization failed') try: if self._token_is_v2(data): bind = data['access']['token']['bind'] elif self._token_is_v3(data): bind = data['token']['bind'] else: raise InvalidUserToken('Token authorization failed') except KeyError: bind = {} # permissive and strict modes don't require there to be a bind permissive = bind_mode in ('permissive', 'strict') if not bind: if permissive: # no bind provided and none required return else: self.LOG.info("No bind information present in token") raise InvalidUserToken('Token authorization failed') # get the named mode if bind_mode is not one of the known name = None if permissive or bind_mode == 'required' else bind_mode if name and name not in bind: self.LOG.info("Named bind mode %s not in bind information", name) raise InvalidUserToken('Token authorization failed') for bind_type, identifier in bind.iteritems(): if bind_type == 'kerberos': if not env.get('AUTH_TYPE', '').lower() == 'negotiate': self.LOG.info("Kerberos credentials required and " "not present") raise InvalidUserToken('Token authorization failed') if not env.get('REMOTE_USER') == identifier: self.LOG.info("Kerberos credentials do not match " "those in bind") raise InvalidUserToken('Token authorization failed') self.LOG.debug("Kerberos bind authentication successful") elif bind_mode == 'permissive': self.LOG.debug("Ignoring Unknown bind for permissive mode: " "{%s: %s}", bind_type, identifier) else: self.LOG.info("Couldn't verify unknown bind: {%s: %s}", bind_type, identifier) raise InvalidUserToken('Token authorization failed') return self._validate_user_token(user_token, env, False)

commit_message:
Add tests for scoped engine

To ensure that scoping is working as expected add a few
tests to the engine testing suite that test the scoping
functionality.

Change-Id: Ia280c89ae9302c9cfca99e035d595f21f48af1e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/87/66087/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

len(values) self.assertEqual(0, item_count) engine.run() storages = self._flow_storages(engine.storages, True) self.assertEqual(0, len(storages['flow-1'])) self.assertEqual(1, len(storages['flow-2'])) subject: New container sync configuration option
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-08 09:25:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/222482c6345a6ac2f9c42b9e74ba5cc6c69e5971', 'message': 'First draft of new container sync configuration

Still a work-in-progress, but submitted in case any want to give
early feedback. This should mosty be "code complete", but needs tests
for all the new stuff. Of course, it's only pre-review code complete.

Summary of the new configuration option:

The cluster operators create a container_sync_realms.conf for their
cluster and copy this out to all their proxy and container servers.
This file specifies the available container sync "realms".

A container sync realm is a group of clusters with a shared key that
have agreed to provide container syncing to one another.

The end user can then set the X-Container-Sync-To value on a
container to //realm/cluster/account/container instead of the
previously required URL.

The allowed hosts list is not used with this configuration and
instead every container sync request sent is signed using the realm
key and user key.

This offers better security as source hosts can be faked much more
easily than faking per request signatures. Replaying signed requests,
assuming it could easily be done, shouldn't be an issue as the
X-Timestamp is part of the signature and so would just short-circuit
as already current or as superceded.

This also makes configuration easier for the end user, especially
with difficult networking situations where a different host might
need to be used for the container sync daemon since it's connecting
from within a cluster. With this new configuration option, the end
user just specifies the realm and cluster names and that is resolved
to the proper endpoint configured by the operator. If the operator
changes their configuration (key or endpoint), the end user does not
need to change theirs.

Change-Id: Ie1704990b66d0434e4991e26ed1da8b08cb05a37
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-12-08 09:33:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/4354829aae8ba6138de19724c311fce5d009e99d', 'message': 'First draft of new container sync configuration

Still a work-in-progress, but submitted in case any want to give
early feedback. This should mosty be "code complete", but needs tests
for all the new stuff. Of course, it's only pre-review code complete.

Summary of the new configuration option:

The cluster operators add the container_sync middleware to their
proxy pipeline and create a container_sync_realms.conf for their
cluster and copy this out to all their proxy and container servers.
This file specifies the available container sync "realms".

A container sync realm is a group of clusters with a shared key that
have agreed to provide container syncing to one another.

The end user can then set the X-Container-Sync-To value on a
container to //realm/cluster/account/container instead of the
previously required URL.

The allowed hosts list is not used with this configuration and
instead every container sync request sent is signed using the realm
key and user key.

This offers better security as source hosts can be faked much more
easily than faking per request signatures. Replaying signed requests,
assuming it could easily be done, shouldn't be an issue as the
X-Timestamp is part of the signature and so would just short-circuit
as already current or as superceded.

This also makes configuration easier for the end user, especially
with difficult networking situations where a different host might
need to be used for the container sync daemon since it's connecting
from within a cluster. With this new configuration option, the end
user just specifies the realm and cluster names and that is resolved
to the proper endpoint configured by the operator. If the operator
changes their configuration (key or endpoint), the end user does not
need to change theirs.

Change-Id: Ie1704990b66d0434e4991e26ed1da8b08cb05a37

commit_message:
New container sync configuration option

Summary of the new configuration option:

The cluster operators add the container_sync middleware to their
proxy pipeline and create a container-sync-realms.conf for their
cluster and copy this out to all their proxy and container servers.
This file specifies the available container sync "realms".

A container sync realm is a group of clusters with a shared key that
have agreed to provide container syncing to one another.

The end user can then set the X-Container-Sync-To value on a
container to //realm/cluster/account/container instead of the
previously required URL.

The allowed hosts list is not used with this configuration and
instead every container sync request sent is signed using the realm
key and user key.

This offers better security as source hosts can be faked much more
easily than faking per request signatures. Replaying signed requests,
assuming it could easily be done, shouldn't be an issue as the
X-Timestamp is part of the signature and so would just short-circuit
as already current or as superceded.

This also makes configuration easier for the end user, especially
with difficult networking situations where a different host might
need to be used for the container sync daemon since it's connecting
from within a cluster. With this new configuration option, the end
user just specifies the realm and cluster names and that is resolved
to the proper endpoint configured by the operator. If the operator
changes their configuration (key or endpoint), the end user does not
need to change theirs.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ie1704990b66d0434e4991e26ed1da8b08cb05a37

commit_message:
Fix showing events on swift.

We don't need to auth again since we already have a valid preauthurl and
preauthtoken already.

Change-Id: Ic48b1bfccaef8f47b46fffb5a014a05b0ce37a9c
Closes-Bug: 1263799

commit_message:
libvirt, fix test tpool_execute_calls_libvirt

An exception raised by mock for expected method is obscured
by the "catch Exception" on libvirt/driver.py#643.

This patch updates the test to be more coherent with the code.

Change-Id: I629634395d11432f9d7e4fbe330b864490fa1801

commit_message:
Implements Nova FloatingIP resources

    https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/nova-networking-floatingip

This code aims to add support OS::Nova::FloatingIP
and OS::Nova::FloatingIPAssociation in Heat.

Change-Id: I678f8a099b97c0fb46bf1056203fc9bafe3032aa
Implements: blueprint nova-networking-floatingip
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/36/62836/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from heat.engine import clients from heat.engine import properties from heat.engine import resource from heat.common import exception from heat.openstack.common import excutils from heat.openstack.common import log as logging from heat.openstack.common.gettextutils import _ logger = logging.getLogger(__name__) class NovaFloatingIp(resource.Resource): PROPERTIES = (POOL,) = ('pool',) properties_schema = { POOL: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, description=_('Allocate a floating IP from a given ' 'floating IP pool.') ), } attributes_schema = { 'pool': _('Pool from which floating IP is allocated.'), 'ip': _('Allocated floating IP address.') } def __init__(self, name, json_snippet, stack): super(NovaFloatingIp, self).__init__(name, json_snippet, stack) self.floating_ip = None def _get_resource(self): if self.floating_ip is None and self.resource_id is not None: self.floating_ip = self.nova().floating_ips.get(self.resource_id) return self.floating_ip def handle_create(self): try: pool = self.properties.get(self.POOL) floating_ip = self.nova().floating_ips.create(pool=pool) except clients.novaclient.exceptions.NotFound: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): logger.error(_('No default floating IP pool is configured.')) return self.resource_id_set(floating_ip.id) self.floating_ip = floating_ip def handle_delete(self): if self.resource_id is not None: try: self.nova().floating_ips.delete(self.resource_id) except clients.novaclient.exceptions.NotFound: pass def _resolve_attribute(self, key): floating_ip = self._get_resource() attributes = { 'pool': floating_ip.pool, 'ip': floating_ip.ip } return unicode(attributes[key]) class NovaFloatingIpAssociation(resource.Resource): PROPERTIES = ( SERVER, FLOATING_IP ) = ( 'server_id', 'floating_ip' ) properties_schema = { SERVER: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Server to assign floating IP to.'), required=True ), FLOATING_IP: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Floating IP that going to be assigned to the server.'), required=True ), } def FnGetRefId(self): return unicode(self.physical_resource_name()) def handle_create(self): server = self.nova().servers.get(self.properties[self.SERVER]) fl_ip = self.nova().floating_ips.get(self.properties[self.FLOATING_IP]) server.add_floating_ip(fl_ip.ip) self.resource_id_set('%s-%s' % (fl_ip.id, fl_ip.ip)) def handle_delete(self): try: server = self.nova().servers.get(self.properties[self.SERVER]) if server: server.remove_floating_ip(self.properties[self.FLOATING_IP]) except clients.novaclient.exceptions.NotFound: pass def resource_mapping(): return { 'OS::Nova::FloatingIP': NovaFloatingIp, 'OS::Nova::FloatingIPAssociation': NovaFloatingIpAssociation, }

commit_message:
Allow passed-in TE_DATAFILE environments.

Adding --existing-environment when invoking devtest.sh will now skip
setting up the test environment. This is useful for either folk
running with baremetal, or TripleO-CI which is using externally
provisioned VMs.

Change-Id: Iea34f22e91d6476614d027d6188037ee541277cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/43/66243/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo " --trash-my-machine -- make nontrivial destructive changes to the machine." echo " For details read the source." echo " -c -- re-use existing source/images if they exist." echo " --existing-environment -- use an existing test environment. The JSON file" echo " for it may be overridden via the TE_DATAFILE" echo " environment variable." echo "Note that this script just chains devtest_variables, devtest_setup," echo "devtest_testenv, devtest_ramdisk, devtest_seed, devtest_undercloud," echo "devtest_overcloud, devtest_end. If you want to run less than all of them just" echo "run the steps you want in order after sourcing ~/.devtestrc and" echo "devtest_variables.sh"RESET_TESTENV=1 TEMP=`getopt -o h,c -l existing-environment,trash-my-machine -n $SCRIPT_NAME -- "$@"` --existing-environment) RESET_TESTENV=; shift 1;;if [ -n "RESET_TESTENV" ]; then #nodocsfi #nodocs
deleted_lines: echo " --trash-my-machine -- make nontrivial destructive changes to the machine." echo " For details read the source." echo " -c -- re-use existing source/images if they exist." echo "Note that this script just chains devtest_setup, devtest_seed, devtest_ramdisk" echo "devtest_undercloud, devtest_overcloud, devtest_end. If you want to run less" echo "than all of them just source each step in order after sourcing ~/.devtestrc." TEMP=`getopt -o h,c -l trash-my-machine -n $SCRIPT_NAME -- "$@"`

commit_message:
Create and use a JSON testenvironment file.

This is the format that TripleO-CI will be passing test environments
through to devtest, so by using it ourselves we avoid special casing
things quite so much.

Using a JSON testenvironment file also permits partially fixing a
FIXME in devtest.sh to stop sourcing some of the devtest scripts.

Change-Id: Ic3b0b482f411427ac8411591edc793e32401310f

deleted_lines: source devtest_setup.sh $CONTINUE source devtest_testenv.sh $TE_DATAFILE

commit_message:
No longer export DEPLOY_IMAGE_ELEMENT

While working towards no longer sourcing the children scripts to remove
some of the sharp edges of devtest, ramdisk can be overridden by the
parent, so DEPLOY_IMAGE_ELEMENT no longer needs to be exported.

Change-Id: Iba7f45f525c85fd3203d3aa0bd97a426ad51ce7f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/57/66157/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DEPLOY_IMAGE_ELEMENT=${DEPLOY_IMAGE_ELEMENT:-deploy}
deleted_lines: export DEPLOY_IMAGE_ELEMENT=${DEPLOY_IMAGE_ELEMENT:-deploy}

commit_message:
Populate devtest_variables from devtest_setup.

Shift great hunks from devtest_setup (all of the things like exporting
variables) into devtest_variables. This allows developers to just
source devtest_variables.sh into their environment to run the other
scripts that depend on the variables existing in the environment.

Change-Id: Idd412616a547c5af1c13ead8bcdc911a26c5527b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/80/66180/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ "$NODE_DIST" == 'unsupported' ]; then
deleted_lines: ## #. The devtest scripts require access to the libvirt system URI. ## If running against a different libvirt URI you may encounter errors. ## Export LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI to prevent devtest using qemu:///system ## Check that the default libvirt connection for your user is qemu:///system. ## If it is not, set an environment variable to configure the connection. ## This configuration is necessary for consistency, as later steps assume ## qemu:///system is being used. ## :: export LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI=${LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI:-"qemu:///system"} ## #. The vm's created by devtest will use e1000 network device emulation by ## default. This can be overriden to use a different network driver for ## interfaces instead, such as virtio. virtio provides faster network ## performance than e1000, but may prove to be less stable. ## :: export LIBVIRT_NIC_DRIVER=${LIBVIRT_NIC_DRIVER:-"e1000"} ## #. Choose a base location to put all of the source code. ## :: ## # exports are ephemeral - new shell sessions, or reboots, and you need ## # to redo them, or use $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-incubator/scripts/write-tripleorc ## # and then source the generated tripleorc file. ## export TRIPLEO_ROOT=~/tripleo export TRIPLEO_ROOT=${TRIPLEO_ROOT:-~/.cache/tripleo} #nodocs## #. Set HW resources for VMs used as 'baremetal' nodes. NODE_CPU is cpu count, ## NODE_MEM is memory (MB), NODE_DISK is disk size (GB), NODE_ARCH is ## architecture (i386, amd64). NODE_ARCH is used also for the seed VM. ## A note on memory sizing: TripleO images in raw form are currently ## ~2.7Gb, which means that a tight node will end up with a thrashing page ## cache during glance -> local + local -> raw operations. This significantly ## impairs performance. Of the four minimum VMs for TripleO simulation, two ## are nova baremetal nodes (seed an undercloud) and these need to be 2G or ## larger. The hypervisor host in the overcloud also needs to be a decent size ## or it cannot host more than one VM. ## ## 32bit VMs:: ## ## export NODE_CPU=1 NODE_MEM=2048 NODE_DISK=20 NODE_ARCH=i386 export NODE_CPU=${NODE_CPU:-1} NODE_MEM=${NODE_MEM:-2048} NODE_DISK=${NODE_DISK:-20} NODE_ARCH=${NODE_ARCH:-i386} #nodocs ## For 64bit it is better to create VMs with more memory and storage because of ## increased memory footprint:: ## ## export NODE_CPU=1 NODE_MEM=2048 NODE_DISK=20 NODE_ARCH=amd64 ## ## #. Set distribution used for VMs (fedora, ubuntu). ## :: ## ## export NODE_DIST=ubuntu ## ## for Fedora set SELinux permissive mode. ## :: ## ## export NODE_DIST="fedora selinux-permissive" ### --end source $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-incubator/scripts/set-os-type if [ "$TRIPLEO_OS_DISTRO" == 'unsupported' ]; thenexport NODE_DIST=${NODE_DIST:-"$TRIPLEO_OS_DISTRO"} ### --include ## #. Set the default bare metal power manager. By default devtest uses ## nova.virt.baremetal.virtual_power_driver.VirtualPowerManager to ## support a fully virtualized TripleO test environment. You may ## optionally customize this setting if you are using real baremetal ## hardware with the devtest scripts. This setting controls the ## power manager used in both the seed VM and undercloud. ## :: export POWER_MANAGER=${POWER_MANAGER:-'nova.virt.baremetal.virtual_power_driver.VirtualPowerManager'} ## #. Set a list of image elements that should be included in all image builds. ## Note that stackuser is only for debugging support - it is not suitable for ## a production network. This is also the place to include elements such as ## pip-cache or pypi-openstack if you intend to use them. ## :: export DIB_COMMON_ELEMENTS=${DIB_COMMON_ELEMENTS:-"stackuser"}## #. You need to make the tripleo image elements accessible to diskimage-builder: ## :: export ELEMENTS_PATH=$TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-image-elements/elements

commit_message:
Start to split devtest_setup out more.

The goal of this effort is to be able to not create VM's during
devtest, so that CI can work with it's predefined environments.
Separately, for folk doing devtest steps by hand, having a safe thing
we can source, separate from the active script that installs packages
etc, seems like a good idea. Thus _testenv and _variables. Of course,
keeping the narrative intact is tricky too - so this patch just sets
up the layout, allowing me and StevenK to work in parallel on the
splitout.

The new TE_DATAFILE variable identifies the test environment file we
will write (in this case) or use (in the TOCI case).

Change-Id: I2cff0bfd09dcaff1e118f519b8d81a74496c6568

commit_message:
Fixes bug 1264418 for Tempest Nova

Changes assertEqual to assertTrue with issubset, that the expected
metadata key/value is a subset of actual metadata from resource,
allowing third-party driver to write metadata for its own purpose.

Fixes: bug #1264418
Change-Id: I653b66da67d5cd6929384309eb757d2b47134084
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/15/65215/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(expected, resp_metadata) self.assertEqual(expected, resp_metadata) self.assertEqual(expected, resp_metadata) self.assertEqual(expected, resp_metadata) expected = {'key2': 'value2'} self.assertEqual(expected, resp_metadata)

subject: Move all SLO functionality to middleware
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-15 23:09:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/9991235627407dc996ff0f95192b56aff77532b6', 'message': 'Move all SLO functionality to middleware

This way, with zero additional effort, SLO will support any future
enhancements made to object storage and retrieval, such as:
 * automatic retry of GETs on broken connection (proxy <-> backend)
 * storage policies
 * erasure-coded object segments

This also lets SLOs work with other sorts of hypothetical third-party
middleware, for example object compression or encryption.

NOTE TO DEPLOYERS: You'll need to copy the "rate_limit_after_segment"
and "rate_limit_segments_per_sec" from the proxy server's
configuration stanza ("app:proxy-server") to the SLO middleware's
configuration stanza. Otherwise, those settings will revert to
default. (SLO's defaults are the same as the proxy's defaults, so if
you haven't changed those settings, no action needs to be taken.)

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ic11662eb5c7176fbf422a6fc87a569928d6f85a1
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-11-20 03:18:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/5d901648cd029e32a29c196772fcd253b58bea7b', 'message': 'Move all SLO functionality to middleware

This way, with zero additional effort, SLO will support any future
enhancements made to object storage and retrieval, such as:
 * automatic retry of GETs on broken connection (proxy <-> backend)
 * storage policies
 * erasure-coded object segments

This also lets SLOs work with other sorts of hypothetical third-party
middleware, for example object compression or encryption.

Getting COPY to work here is sort of a hack; the proxy's object
controller now checks for "swift.copy_response_hook" in the request's
environment and feeds the GET response (the source of the new object's
data) through it. This lets a COPY of a SLO manifest actually combine
the segments instead of merely copying the manifest document.

NOTE TO DEPLOYERS: You'll need to copy the "rate_limit_after_segment"
and "rate_limit_segments_per_sec" from the proxy server's
configuration stanza ("app:proxy-server") to the SLO middleware's
configuration stanza. Otherwise, those settings will revert to
default. (SLO's defaults are the same as the proxy's defaults, so if
you haven't changed those settings, no action needs to be taken.)

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ic11662eb5c7176fbf422a6fc87a569928d6f85a1
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2013-11-22 18:59:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/5109e55b7486eb9bc2e7bec2c60736b5b328f25f', 'message': 'Move all SLO functionality to middleware

This way, with zero additional effort, SLO will support any future
enhancements made to object storage and retrieval, such as:
 * automatic retry of GETs on broken connection (proxy <-> backend)
 * storage policies
 * erasure-coded object segments

This also lets SLOs work with other sorts of hypothetical third-party
middleware, for example object compression or encryption.

Getting COPY to work here is sort of a hack; the proxy's object
controller now checks for "swift.copy_response_hook" in the request's
environment and feeds the GET response (the source of the new object's
data) through it. This lets a COPY of a SLO manifest actually combine
the segments instead of merely copying the manifest document.

NOTE TO DEPLOYERS: You'll need to copy the "rate_limit_after_segment"
and "rate_limit_segments_per_sec" from the proxy server's
configuration stanza ("app:proxy-server") to the SLO middleware's
configuration stanza. Otherwise, those settings will revert to
default. (SLO's defaults are the same as the proxy's defaults, so if
you haven't changed those settings, no action needs to be taken.)

DocImpact

blueprint multi-ring-large-objects

'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2013-11-27 22:14:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/6ec50164388932dcc663602140117e2778ca4d3c', 'message': 'Move all SLO functionality to middleware

This way, with zero additional effort, SLO will support any future
enhancements made to object storage and retrieval, such as:
 * automatic retry of GETs on broken connection (proxy <-> backend)
 * storage policies
 * erasure-coded object segments

This also lets SLOs work with other sorts of hypothetical third-party
middleware, for example object compression or encryption.

Getting COPY to work here is sort of a hack; the proxy's object
controller now checks for "swift.copy_response_hook" in the request's
environment and feeds the GET response (the source of the new object's
data) through it. This lets a COPY of a SLO manifest actually combine
the segments instead of merely copying the manifest document.

NOTE TO DEPLOYERS: You'll need to copy the "rate_limit_after_segment"
and "rate_limit_segments_per_sec" from the proxy server's
configuration stanza ("app:proxy-server") to the SLO middleware's
configuration stanza. Otherwise, those settings will revert to
default. (SLO's defaults are the same as the proxy's defaults, so if
you haven't changed those settings, no action needs to be taken.)

DocImpact

blueprint multi-ring-large-objects

This way, with zero additional effort, SLO will support any future
enhancements made to object storage and retrieval, such as:
 * automatic retry of GETs on broken connection (proxy <-> backend)
 * storage policies
 * erasure-coded object segments

This also lets SLOs work with other sorts of hypothetical third-party
middleware, for example object compression or encryption.

Getting COPY to work here is sort of a hack; the proxy's object
controller now checks for "swift.copy_response_hook" in the request's
environment and feeds the GET response (the source of the new object's
